title: How to Make Coconut Truffles

steps.headline: Melt the coconut oil.
steps.description: If it is already melted, then skip this step.

steps.headline: Place all of the ingredients into the blender or food processor.
steps.description: Blend or process until a smooth paste is formed.

steps.headline: Remove the mixture.
steps.description: Take about one teaspoon's worth of mixture and shape a ball from it.

steps.headline: Roll the ball in the coconut, to coat.
steps.description: Place the completed ball on a baking tray or sheet lined with parchment or greaseproof paper.

steps.headline: Repeat until all of the mixture has been turned into coconut truffles.
steps.description: Place a cover of kitchen food wrap over the top.

steps.headline: Place the covered tray or sheet in the refrigerator.
steps.description: Allow to sit for half an hour to an hour, or until set.

steps.headline: Serve.
steps.description: If not serving the same day, store in an airtight container in the fridge.

steps.headline: Place the cream cheese in a mixing bowl.
steps.description: Add the coconut extract. Mix together.

steps.headline: Add the powdered sugar to the mixture.
steps.description: Also add a half cup of shredded coconut to the mixture gradually, beating it in as you go. Mix until a smooth truffle mix forms.

steps.headline: Shape the truffles.
steps.description: Take about a teaspoon's worth of mixture and shape into small balls.

steps.headline: Roll in the coconut to cover.
steps.description: Arrange the finished truffle on a baking sheet or tray lined with parchment or greaseproof paper.

steps.headline: Continue making all the truffles, until the mixture is exhausted.
Cover with a layer of kitchen plastic wrap.
steps.description: Place in the refrigerator for 15 minutes to half an hour, or until set.

steps.headline: Serve.
steps.description: If not serving immediately, store in an airtight container in the fridge.

steps.headline: Place the shredded coconut, cream cheese, confectioners or icing sugar and extract (if using) in the mixer bowl.
steps.description: Mix until smooth.

steps.headline: Take about a teaspoon of the mixture and form a small bowl.
steps.description: Roll it in the palm of your hand. Place the ball onto a baking sheet or tray lined with parchment or greaseproof paper.

steps.headline: Repeat with the remaining truffle mix, until the whole mixture is exhausted.
Place the finished balls into the freezer.
steps.description: Freeze for an hour.

steps.headline: Melt the chocolate.
steps.description: Add the coconut to the chocolate and melt both together. Stir constantly as both are melting. Remove from the heat once melted.

steps.headline: Remove the truffle balls from the freezer.
steps.description: Dip the balls into the melted chocolate and oil mix. Do this using a fork, allowing excess chocolate to drain back into the chocolate mix.

steps.headline: Arrange the dipped truffles onto the same lined baking sheet or tray.
steps.description: The truffles should not be touched; push them off with the teaspoon.

steps.headline: Place in the refrigerator.
steps.description: Leave until set, at least half an hour.

steps.headline: Serve.
steps.description: They are ready once set. If not consuming after they have set, store in an airtight container in the refrigerator.

steps.headline: Put the shredded coconut, almonds, syrup and oil into the food processor.
steps.description: Squeeze in the lemon juice and add some zest.

steps.headline: Process the ingredients until they form a smooth paste.
Take about a teaspoon's worth of mixture.
steps.description: Roll into a neat ball.

steps.headline: Roll the truffle ball in the extra shredded coconut, to coat.
steps.description: Place the completed truffle on a parchment or greaseproof paper lined baking tray or sheet.

steps.headline: Repeat until the mixture is used up.
steps.description: You'll make around 12 to 16 balls using this mixture.

steps.headline: Place the finished truffles in the refrigerator.
steps.description: Chill until the truffles firm up, around a half an hour to an hour.

steps.headline: Serve.
steps.description: Either serve once firmed or store in an airtight container in the fridge.

steps.headline: Place the milk, coconut and coconut oil (or butter) into the saucepan.
Cook the ingredients over medium heat.
steps.description: Cook for 10 to 15 minutes from the time you begin heating the mixture.

steps.headline: Watch for the mixture beginning to pull back from the sides of the saucepan.
steps.description: This means that the mixture is done. Remove from the heat.

steps.headline: Allow to cool.
steps.description: Cooling can be sped up by spreading it on a silicone sheet.

steps.headline: Form small balls from the mixture when the mixture is cool enough to handle.
steps.description: Take about a teaspoon's worth of mixture and roll into a small ball.

steps.headline: Roll the ball in the extra coconut, to coat.
steps.description: Transfer the coated ball to a baking sheet or tray lined with parchment or greaseproof paper. If preferred, the balls can be coated in melted chocolate.

steps.headline: Transfer to the fridge to set.
steps.description: They're now ready to eat. If storing longer, keep in an airtight container in the fridge.

text: Coconut Sultana Truffles Melt the coconut oil. If it is already melted, then skip this step. Place all of the ingredients into the blender or food processor. Blend or process until a smooth paste is formed. Remove the mixture. Take about one teaspoon's worth of mixture and shape a ball from it. Roll the ball in the coconut, to coat. Place the completed ball on a baking tray or sheet lined with parchment or greaseproof paper. Repeat until all of the mixture has been turned into coconut truffles. Place a cover of kitchen food wrap over the top. Place the covered tray or sheet in the refrigerator. Allow to sit for half an hour to an hour, or until set. Serve. If not serving the same day, store in an airtight container in the fridge. Cream Cheese Coconut Truffles Place the cream cheese in a mixing bowl. Add the coconut extract. Mix together. Add the powdered sugar to the mixture. Also add a half cup of shredded coconut to the mixture gradually, beating it in as you go. Mix until a smooth truffle mix forms. Shape the truffles. Take about a teaspoon's worth of mixture and shape into small balls. Roll in the coconut to cover. Arrange the finished truffle on a baking sheet or tray lined with parchment or greaseproof paper. Continue making all the truffles, until the mixture is exhausted.  Cover with a layer of kitchen plastic wrap. Place in the refrigerator for 15 minutes to half an hour, or until set. Serve. If not serving immediately, store in an airtight container in the fridge. Dark Chocolate Coconut Truffles Place the shredded coconut, cream cheese, confectioners or icing sugar and extract (if using) in the mixer bowl. Mix until smooth. Take about a teaspoon of the mixture and form a small bowl. Roll it in the palm of your hand. Place the ball onto a baking sheet or tray lined with parchment or greaseproof paper. Repeat with the remaining truffle mix, until the whole mixture is exhausted.  Place the finished balls into the freezer. Freeze for an hour. Melt the chocolate. Add the coconut to the chocolate and melt both together. Stir constantly as both are melting. Remove from the heat once melted. Remove the truffle balls from the freezer. Dip the balls into the melted chocolate and oil mix. Do this using a fork, allowing excess chocolate to drain back into the chocolate mix. Arrange the dipped truffles onto the same lined baking sheet or tray. The truffles should not be touched; push them off with the teaspoon. Place in the refrigerator. Leave until set, at least half an hour. Serve. They are ready once set. If not consuming after they have set, store in an airtight container in the refrigerator. Lemon and Coconut Truffles Put the shredded coconut, almonds, syrup and oil into the food processor. Squeeze in the lemon juice and add some zest. Process the ingredients until they form a smooth paste.  Take about a teaspoon's worth of mixture. Roll into a neat ball. Roll the truffle ball in the extra shredded coconut, to coat. Place the completed truffle on a parchment or greaseproof paper lined baking tray or sheet. Repeat until the mixture is used up. You'll make around 12 to 16 balls using this mixture. Place the finished truffles in the refrigerator. Chill until the truffles firm up, around a half an hour to an hour. Serve. Either serve once firmed or store in an airtight container in the fridge. Brazilian Coconut Truffles (Beijinhos) Place the milk, coconut and coconut oil (or butter) into the saucepan.  Cook the ingredients over medium heat. Cook for 10 to 15 minutes from the time you begin heating the mixture. Watch for the mixture beginning to pull back from the sides of the saucepan. This means that the mixture is done. Remove from the heat. Allow to cool. Cooling can be sped up by spreading it on a silicone sheet. Form small balls from the mixture when the mixture is cool enough to handle. Take about a teaspoon's worth of mixture and roll into a small ball. Roll the ball in the extra coconut, to coat. Transfer the coated ball to a baking sheet or tray lined with parchment or greaseproof paper. If preferred, the balls can be coated in melted chocolate. Transfer to the fridge to set. They're now ready to eat. If storing longer, keep in an airtight container in the fridge.
tyn_model: parchment or greaseproof paper lined baking tray
